informal_statement: Suppose $m$ is a two-digit positive integer such that $6^{-1}\pmod m$ exists and $6^{-1}\equiv 6^2\pmod m$. What is $m$? Show that it is 43.
informal_proof:
We can multiply both sides of the congruence $6^{-1}\equiv 6^2\pmod m$ by $6$: $$
\underbrace{6\cdot 6^{-1}}_1 \equiv \underbrace{6\cdot 6^2}_{6^3} \pmod m.
$$Thus $6^3-1=215$ is a multiple of $m$. We know that $m$ has two digits. The only two-digit positive divisor of $215$ is $43$, so $m=43$.
formal_statement:
theorem mathd_numbertheory_780:
  fixes m x :: nat
  assumes h0 : "10 \<le> m"
    and h1 : "m \<le> 99"
    and h2 : "(6 * x) mod m = 1"
    and h3 : "(x - 6^2) mod m = 0"
  shows "m = 43"
formal_code:
(*
  Authors: Albert Qiaochu Jiang
*)

theory mathd_numbertheory_780 imports
Complex_Main

begin

theorem mathd_numbertheory_780:
  fixes m x :: nat
  assumes h0 : "10 \<le> m"
    and h1 : "m \<le> 99"
    and h2 : "(6 * x) mod m = 1"
    and h3 : "(x - 6^2) mod m = 0"
  shows "m = 43"
  sorry

end
